articles.headline: Reddit Rises 48% in First Day of Trading
articles.snippet: The social media company’s debut on the New York Stock Exchange was one of the first major tech initial public offerings of the year.
articles.abstract: The social media company’s debut on the New York Stock Exchange was one of the first major tech initial public offerings of the year.
articles.lead_paragraph: Reddit shares rose 48 percent on Thursday in their first day of trading, in a sign of investor eagerness that set the stage for more tech companies to reach the stock market this year.
articles.byline: By Mike Isaac and Lauren Hirsch

articles.headline: A Little-Known Way That Trump Could Raise Money to Pay His Legal Bills
articles.snippet: The former president’s social media company is finally set to go public. He could borrow against the value of his stake in the company.
articles.abstract: The former president’s social media company is finally set to go public. He could borrow against the value of his stake in the company.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shares of former President Donald J. Trump’s social media company could start trading on the stock market as early as Monday, immediately raising his net worth by around $3 billion — wealth that Mr. Trump may be able to tap to pay his mounting legal bills as he seeks a second presidential term.

articles.headline: In One Key A.I. Metric, China Pulls Ahead of the U.S.: Talent
articles.snippet: China has produced a huge number of top A.I. engineers in recent years. New research shows that, by some measures, it has already eclipsed the United States.
articles.abstract: China has produced a huge number of top A.I. engineers in recent years. New research shows that, by some measures, it has already eclipsed the United States.
articles.lead_paragraph: When it comes to the artificial intelligence that powers chatbots like ChatGPT, China lags behind the United States. But when it comes to producing the scientists behind a new generation of humanoid technologies, China is pulling ahead.
articles.byline: By Paul Mozur and Cade Metz

articles.headline: With TikTok Under Fire, Brands That Rely on It Worry
articles.snippet: Many companies, particularly in the beauty and fashion industries, have boosted sales through the platform. They don’t really have a backup plan.
articles.abstract: Many companies, particularly in the beauty and fashion industries, have boosted sales through the platform. They don’t really have a backup plan.
articles.lead_paragraph: Amid debate in Washington over whether TikTok should be banned if its Chinese owner doesn’t sell it, one group is watching with particular interest: the many brands — particularly in the beauty, skin care, fashion, and health and wellness industries — that have used the video app to boost their sales.
articles.byline: By Jordyn Holman and Julie Creswell

articles.headline: What Happened When India Pulled the Plug on TikTok
articles.snippet: The United States is agonizing over the possibility of a ban, but India did it at a stroke. Indians adjusted quickly, and Instagram and YouTube built big audiences.
articles.abstract: The United States is agonizing over the possibility of a ban, but India did it at a stroke. Indians adjusted quickly, and Instagram and YouTube built big audiences.
articles.lead_paragraph: In India, a country of 1.4 billion, it took TikTok just a few years to build an audience of 200 million users. India was its biggest market. Then, on June 29, 2020, the Indian government banned TikTok, along with 58 other Chinese apps, after a simmering conflict between India and China flared into violence at their border.
articles.byline: By Alex Travelli and Suhasini Raj

articles.headline: Inside Garland’s Effort to Prosecute Trump
articles.snippet: In trying to avoid even the smallest mistakes, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland might have made one big one: ending up in a race against the clock.
articles.abstract: In trying to avoid even the smallest mistakes, Attorney General Merrick B. Garland might have made one big one: ending up in a race against the clock.
articles.lead_paragraph: After being sworn in as attorney general in March 2021, Merrick B. Garland gathered his closest aides to discuss a topic too sensitive to broach in bigger groups: the possibility that evidence from the far-ranging Jan. 6 investigation could quickly lead to former President Donald J. Trump and his inner circle.
articles.byline: By Glenn Thrush and Adam Goldman

articles.headline: The Trustbuster Who Has Apple and Google in His Sights
articles.snippet: Jonathan Kanter, the head of the Justice Department’s antitrust division, made his boldest move on Thursday by accusing Apple of antitrust violations.
articles.abstract: Jonathan Kanter, the head of the Justice Department’s antitrust division, made his boldest move on Thursday by accusing Apple of antitrust violations.
articles.lead_paragraph: Shortly after Jonathan Kanter took over the Justice Department’s antitrust division in November 2021, the agency secured an additional $50 million to investigate monopolies, bust criminal cartels and block mergers.

articles.headline: Utility-Caused Wildfires Are Becoming a National Problem
articles.snippet: Climate change is raising the risk of blazes that are started by power lines and other utility equipment in many parts of the U.S. besides California.
articles.abstract: Climate change is raising the risk of blazes that are started by power lines and other utility equipment in many parts of the U.S. besides California.
articles.lead_paragraph: After a utility pole fell and ignited a wildfire, Frank King and his family raced to escape as electrical transformers exploded around their homes near Oregon’s coast. A bright red glow was visible in the rearview mirror for miles.

articles.headline: The A.C.L.U. Said a Worker Used Racist Tropes and Fired Her. But Did She?
articles.snippet: The civil liberties group is defending itself in an unusual case that weighs what kind of language may be evidence of bias against Black people.
articles.abstract: The civil liberties group is defending itself in an unusual case that weighs what kind of language may be evidence of bias against Black people.
articles.lead_paragraph: Kate Oh was no one’s idea of a get-along-to-go-along employee.

articles.headline: Congress Passes Spending Bill in Wee Hours to Fend Off Shutdown
articles.snippet: After hours of delay, the Senate overwhelmingly voted for the $1.2 trillion bill to fund more than half of the government, sending the measure to President Biden’s desk.
articles.abstract: After hours of delay, the Senate overwhelmingly voted for the $1.2 trillion bill to fund more than half of the government, sending the measure to President Biden’s desk.
articles.lead_paragraph: The Senate overwhelmingly gave final approval early Saturday to a $1.2 trillion spending bill to fund more than half of the government, effectively averting a shutdown by sending the legislation to President Biden’s desk just hours after a midnight deadline.

articles.headline: Investors Pour Money Into Wall St. as Stocks Set New Highs
articles.snippet: The influx of cash reflects optimism about the economy and company earnings despite high interest rates and stubborn inflation.
articles.abstract: The influx of cash reflects optimism about the economy and company earnings despite high interest rates and stubborn inflation.
articles.lead_paragraph: It looks like there is little that can trouble investors at the moment.
